me.tatarka.ipromise.buffer

Class PromiseBuffers

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.tatarka.ipromise.buffer.PromiseBuffers

  • public class PromiseBuffers
extends java.lang.Object
    Useful utility methods for creating a PromiseBuffer.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> all()
      Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores all messages.
      static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> fixed(int capcity)
      Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores a number of messages up to the given capacity.
      static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> last()
      Creates a PromiseBuffer that only stores the last message that was sent.
      static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> none()
      Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores no messages.
      static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> ofType(int type)
      Returns a PromiseBuffer for the given enumeration.
      static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> ring(int capacity)
      Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores messages in a ring buffer of the given capacity.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • none

        public static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> none()
        Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores no messages. This means that if there is no Listener attached when the message is sent, it will be dropped. Use this if you don't care if messages are dropped.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the message type
        Returns:
        the PromiseBuffer

      • last

        public static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> last()
        Creates a PromiseBuffer that only stores the last message that was sent. The is the default if no buffer is specified because it most closely matches a standard Future implementation when only one message is sent.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the message type
        Returns:
        the PromiseBuffer

      • all

        public static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> all()
        Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores all messages. Use this if you want to be sure that no messages will be dropped. Note: be careful about memory usage since all messages will be kept in memory until the Promise is garbage collected.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the message type
        Returns:
        the PromiseBuffer

      • ring

        public static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> ring(int capacity)
        Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores messages in a ring buffer of the given capacity. In other words, when there is no more room for a message, it will replace the oldest once. Use this if you want to allow some messages to drop if you get too many.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the message type
        Parameters:
        capacity - the number of messages received before it will start replacing old ones
        Returns:
        the PromiseBuffer

      • fixed

        public static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> fixed(int capcity)
        Creates a PromiseBuffer that stores a number of messages up to the given capacity. Sending any more messages will cause an IllegalStateException to be thrown. Use this is you know exactly how many messages will be sent and you want to enforce that.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the message type
        Parameters:
        capcity - the maximum number of message
        Returns:
        the PromiseBuffer

      • ofType

        public static <T> PromiseBuffer<T> ofType(int type)
        Returns a PromiseBuffer for the given enumeration. This is a convenience method so that you can use an enumeration directly for common buffer types.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the message type
        Parameters:
        type - The buffer type. Valid values are Promise.BUFFER_NONE, Promise.BUFFER_LAST, and Promise.BUFFER_ALL.
        Returns:
        the PromiseBuffer
        See Also:
        Promise.BUFFER_NONE, Promise.BUFFER_LAST, Promise.BUFFER_ALL
